The nominal strictness of discipline which should main- tain the authority of the abbot over the convent was without difficulty broken through by the customary agency of appeal to higher powers, The opportunity for this declaration of hostility against their abbot was given by the celebration of a general chapter of the order in England, under authority of pope Boniface IX„ the members of the order in Franco having recognized the rival pope, Clement VII. The chapter was to be held at St. Mary of Gra-ces in London. The antagonistic or in— subordinate members of the convent held a meeting, and ‚appointed by a public instrument two of their number, Rich-ard Esk and Alan Burton, delegates to lay before the chapter the grounds of their protest against the election of Thomas Burton. These were alleged to be, the undue interference in the election by Thomas of Woodstock‚ duke of Gloucester, as founder, who, by power and violence, intruded him upon the convent.
